statements.statement: Gamification in teaching works well in digital environments
Gamification in teaching works well in a face-to-face environment
Gamification is best for teaching when it involves a set of rules
Gamification is best for teaching when it involves play without structure
Gamification is best for teaching when it is based on a storyline i.e. scenario
Gamification is engaging when the student can participate anonymously
In Gamification, it is better to set static game rules without changing them
In Gamification, it is better to adapt the game rules according to the game progression
Gamification in teaching is effective for entertaining and having fun
Gamification in teaching is effective for assessing students
Gamification in teaching is effective for engaging and motivating students
Gamification in teaching is effective in the core course
Gamification in teaching is effective for extra-curricular activity (not part of the core course)
Gamification is engaging when it is related to course marks
Gamification is effective for formative assessment, i.e. assessing student throughout the process (credited)
Gamification is effective for summative assessment, i.e. assessing students at the end (credited)
Gamification is engaging when related to non-monetary rewards, i.e. points, badges
Gamification is engaging when related to monetary rewards – i.e. coffee vouchers
Gamification in teaching focuses on enabling students to achieve learning goals
Gamification is effective when a student is challenging her/himself
Gamification is effective for enhancing the understanding of complex concepts
Gamification is effective in teaching theoretical concepts
Gamification is effective in practice-based learning
Gamification is effective in developing the student’s learning
Gamification is effective for social bonding between students
Gamification is effective for promoting positive social behaviours, i.e. increase attendance of class
Gamification improves the participation of students
Gamification is effective when participants are in teams
Gamification is effective with students who are already friends
Gamification is effective when students work individually
Gamification in education is effective with small classes (not more than 10)
Gamification in teaching is effective with big classes (more than 10)
Gamification is effective if it includes collaborative approaches
Gamification is effective if it includes competitive approaches
Gamification is effective if it includes mixed approaches of collaboration and competition
Gamification allows effective students' collaboration to achieve a common goal
Gamification allows effective competition among students
Gamification is effective if it leads to a common end goal
Gamification is effective if it leads to different end goals from one individual to another
Collaborative gamification can be negatively affected by 'free riders', i.e. under-performers within a group
Gamification in teaching is effective if the teacher is actively involved in the gamification process, i.e. the teacher as a player in the game
Gamification in teaching is effective if the teacher is mentoring the students in the game, i.e. the teacher as a moderator
Gamification in teaching is effective if the teacher observes the gamification process in a non-intrusive way
Teacher’s participation in gamified activities is effective when activities are done online
Teacher’s participation in gamified activities is effective when activities are done face-to-face
Gamification in teaching is effective when it is used throughout the whole course
Gamification in teaching is effective when it is used occasionally
